sn2.18:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sākete viharati añjanavane migadāye.
sn2.18:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa in the deer park at the Añjana Wood.

sn2.18:1.3.pli: Atha kho kakudho devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ añjanavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kakudho devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.18:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Kakudha, lighting up the entire Añjana Wood, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
sn2.18:1.3.comm: A deity of this name, identified as a former Koliyan who had been Mahāmoggallāna’s supporter, reports on Devadatta’s ill intent (AN 5.100, Ud 8.5, Kd 17:2.2.1). Both discourses show a concern for ascetic conduct. At Kd 1:20.2.3, a deity is living in a kakudha tree (arjuna). | There was a river of similar name near Kusināra (DN 16:4.22.5), which could well have flowed through Koliyan country. Variant spellings abound in Pali and Sanskrit.

sn2.18:1.8.pli: “Tena hi, samaṇa, neva nandasi na ca socasī”ti?
sn2.18:1.8.eng: “Well then, ascetic, do you neither delight nor sorrow?”

sn2.18:2.1.comm: The paralleling of agha with soka (“sorrow”) here as the opposites of “delight” help establish the Pali sense of agha as “gloom” rather than the Vedic “sin”.

sn2.18:2.2.eng: I hope that delight isn’t found in you.

sn2.18:2.4.eng: overwhelm you as you sit alone.”

sn2.18:3.2.eng: and no delight is found in me.

sn2.18:3.4.eng: overwhelm me as I sit alone.”

sn2.18:4.2.eng: How is delight not found in you?

sn2.18:4.4.eng: overwhelm you as you sit alone?”

sn2.18:5.3.eng: sir, you should know me as

sn2.18:5.4.eng: a mendicant free of delight and gloom.”

sn2.18:6.3.eng: A mendicant free of delight and gloom,

sn2.18:6.4.eng: he has crossed over clinging to the world.”

sn2.19:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho uttaro devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.19:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Uttara spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.19:1.2.comm: Uttara is a very common name, making identification impossible.

sn2.19:2.1.eng: “This life, so very short, is led onward.

sn2.19:2.2.eng: One led on to old age has no shelter.

sn2.19:2.4.eng: do good deeds that bring you joy.”

sn2.19:3.1.eng: “This life, so very short, is led onward.

sn2.19:3.2.eng: One led on to old age has no shelter.

sn2.19:3.4.eng: a seeker of peace would drop the world’s bait.”

sn2.2:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kassapo devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.2:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Kassapa spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.2:2.1.eng: “If a mendicant is a meditator, freed in mind,

sn2.2:2.2.eng: and if they desire the heart’s fulfillment—

sn2.2:2.3.eng: having known the arising and passing of the world,

sn2.2:2.4.eng: good-hearted, independent, that is their reward.”

sn2.20:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.20:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Anāthapiṇḍika recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.20:1.1.comm: The full story of how Anāthapiṇḍika died and returned to speak these verses is told in (MN 143).

sn2.20:2.2.eng: frequented by the Saṅgha of seers,

sn2.20:2.3.eng: where the King of Dhamma stayed:

sn2.20:4.4.eng: and thus be purified in it.

sn2.20:5.3.eng: Even a mendicant who has crossed over

sn2.20:6.1.eng: This is what the godling Anāthapiṇḍika said.

sn2.20:6.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
sn2.20:6.2.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

sn2.20:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn2.20:7.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn2.20:7.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññataro devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.20:7.2.eng: “Mendicants, tonight, a certain glorious godling, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side,

sn2.20:7.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhikkhave, so devaputto mama santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.20:7.3.eng: and recited these verses in my presence.” The Buddha then repeated the verses in full.

sn2.20:12.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.

sn2.20:13.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.20:13.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

sn2.20:13.2.pli: “so hi nūna, bhante, anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto bhavissati.
sn2.20:13.2.eng: “Sir, that godling must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika.

sn2.20:13.3.pli: Anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati āyasmante sāriputte abhippasanno ahosī”ti.
sn2.20:13.3.eng: For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was devoted to Venerable Sāriputta.”

sn2.20:13.4.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, ānanda, yāvatakaṃ kho, ānanda, takkāya pattabbaṃ anuppattaṃ taṃ tayā.
sn2.20:13.4.eng: “Good, good, Ānanda. You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes.

sn2.20:13.5.eng: For that was indeed the godling Anāthapiṇḍika.”

sn2.21:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn2.21:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn2.21:1.3.pli: Atha kho sivo devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.21:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Shiva, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.21:1.3.comm: This is the only clear appearance of Shiva (siva, “auspicious”, “kindly”) in early Pali (but see Sivaka at SN 10.8). In the Rig Veda he appears a few times under the name Rudra, the “roarer”, where he is feared but approached as dispenser of blessed healing (Rig Veda 2.33). Along with other gods, he is there sometimes described as śiva, “kindly, blessed”. As time went on his kindly aspect became more prominent, but he never lost his destructive side. He was not normally known as Shiva until the Purāṇic period. | The next few deities have names that are similar in meaning: khema, serī.

sn2.21:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sivo devaputto bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.21:1.4.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.21:2.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:2.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:3.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:3.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:3.4.eng: wisdom is gained—but not from anyone else.

sn2.21:4.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:4.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:4.4.eng: you grieve not among the grieving.

sn2.21:5.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:5.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:6.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:6.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:6.4.eng: sentient beings go to a good place.

sn2.21:7.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:7.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.21:8.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sivaṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn2.21:8.1.eng: Then the Buddha replied to Shiva in verse:

sn2.21:9.2.eng: Try to get close to the virtuous!

sn2.21:9.3.eng: Understanding the true teaching of the good,

sn2.22:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho khemo devaputto bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn2.22:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Khema recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.22:1.1.comm: Khema is a common name meaning “safety, blessedness, sanctuary”.

sn2.22:3.1.eng: It’s not good to do a deed

sn2.22:3.3.eng: for which you weep and wail,

sn2.22:3.4.eng: as its effect stays with you.

sn2.22:4.1.eng: It is good to do a deed

sn2.22:4.2.eng: that doesn’t plague you later on,

sn2.22:4.4.eng: as its effect stays with you.”
sn2.22:4.4.comm: I follow Bodhi in finishing the godling’s verses at this point.

sn2.22:5.2.eng: what you know is for your own welfare.

sn2.22:5.3.eng: A thinker, a wise one would not proceed

sn2.22:6.1.eng: Suppose a cart driver leaves the highway,

sn2.22:6.3.eng: They enter upon a rough road,

sn2.22:6.4.eng: and fret as soon as their axle is broken.

sn2.22:7.1.eng: So too, a dullard leaves the good

sn2.22:7.2.eng: to follow what’s against the good.

sn2.22:7.3.eng: Fallen in the jaws of death,
sn2.22:7.3.comm: “Jaws of death” (maccumukha) is also at Snp 4.2:5.3. Compare Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.1.1, “he escapes from the jaws of death” (tanmṛtyumukhātpramucyate).

sn2.22:7.4.eng: they fret like one whose axle is broken.”
sn2.22:7.4.comm: See Bodhi, Connected Discourses note 174 for readings in these verses. | The final line here and in the previous verse are identical in Pali (akkhacchinnova jhāyati) but require different senses. The commentary reads the first as akkhacchinno avajhāyati (“frets with broken axle”) and the second akkhacchinno iva jhāyati (“frets like one whose axle is broken”). The prefixed verb is not necessary for the sense (cp. Snp 4.7:5.2, Dhp 155:3), so instead I take the first line as akkhacchinno eva jhāyati (“frets as soon as their axle is broken”).

sn2.23:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho serī devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.23:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Serī addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.23:1.1.comm: The name serī here is from siri (“auspiciousness, good luck”). He does not appear elsewhere.

sn2.23:2.3.eng: So what’s the name of the spirit

sn2.23:3.2.eng: and a clear and confident heart,

sn2.23:3.4.eng: in this world and the next.

sn2.23:4.2.eng: overcoming that stain, and give a gift.

sn2.23:4.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn2.23:4.4.eng: support them in the next world.”

sn2.23:5.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.” He repeated the Buddha’s verses, and said:

sn2.23:8.1.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, sirī nāma rājā ahosiṃ dāyako dānapati dānassa vaṇṇavādī.
sn2.23:8.1.eng: “Once upon a time, sir, I was a king named Serī, a giver, a donor, who praised giving.
sn2.23:8.1.comm: The moral of this story is echoed in SN 3.18:9.1.

sn2.23:8.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, catūsu dvāresu dānaṃ dīyittha samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavanibbakayācakānaṃ.
sn2.23:8.2.eng: I gave gifts at the four gates to ascetics and brahmins, to paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars.
sn2.23:8.2.comm: Sharing wealth is a moral act. | Dīyittha is passive reflexive aorist of √dā.

sn2.23:8.3.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, itthāgāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn2.23:8.3.eng: Then the ladies of my harem approached me and said,

sn2.23:8.4.pli: ‘devassa kho dānaṃ dīyati; amhākaṃ dānaṃ na dīyati.
sn2.23:8.4.eng: ‘Your Majesty gives gifts, but we don’t.

sn2.23:8.5.pli: Sādhu mayampi devaṃ nissāya dānāni dadeyyāma, puññāni kareyyāmā’ti.
sn2.23:8.5.eng: Your Majesty, please support us to give gifts and make merit.’

sn2.23:8.7.eng: ‘I’m a giver, a donor, who praises giving.

sn2.23:8.8.eng: When they say, “We would give gifts”, what am I to say?’

sn2.23:8.9.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, paṭhamaṃ dvāraṃ itthāgārassa adāsiṃ.
sn2.23:8.9.eng: And so I gave the first gate to the ladies of my harem.

sn2.23:8.10.pli: Tattha itthāgārassa dānaṃ dīyittha; mama dānaṃ paṭikkami.
sn2.23:8.10.eng: There they gave gifts, while my own giving dwindled.
sn2.23:8.10.comm: “Dwindled” is paṭikkami, literally “went backwards”. This sense is also recorded for Sanskrit pratikram.

sn2.23:9.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, khattiyā anuyantā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
sn2.23:9.1.eng: Then my aristocrat vassals approached me and said,

sn2.23:9.2.pli: ‘devassa kho dānaṃ dīyati; itthāgārassa dānaṃ dīyati; amhākaṃ dānaṃ na dīyati.
sn2.23:9.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty gives gifts, the ladies of your harem give gifts, but we don’t.

sn2.23:9.3.pli: Sādhu mayampi devaṃ nissāya dānāni dadeyyāma, puññāni kareyyāmā’ti.
sn2.23:9.3.eng: Your Majesty, please support us to give gifts and make merit.’

sn2.23:9.5.eng: ‘I’m a giver, a donor, who praises giving.

sn2.23:9.6.eng: When they say, “We would give gifts”, what am I to say?’

sn2.23:9.7.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, dutiyaṃ dvāraṃ khattiyānaṃ anuyantānaṃ adāsiṃ.
sn2.23:9.7.eng: And so I gave the second gate to my aristocrat vassals.

sn2.23:9.8.pli: Tattha khattiyānaṃ anuyantānaṃ dānaṃ dīyittha, mama dānaṃ paṭikkami.
sn2.23:9.8.eng: There they gave gifts, while my own giving dwindled.

sn2.23:10.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, balakāyo upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn2.23:10.1.eng: Then my troops approached me and said,

sn2.23:10.2.pli: ‘devassa kho dānaṃ dīyati; itthāgārassa dānaṃ dīyati; khattiyānaṃ anuyantānaṃ dānaṃ dīyati; amhākaṃ dānaṃ na dīyati.
sn2.23:10.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty gives gifts, the ladies of your harem give gifts, your aristocrat vassals give gifts, but we don’t.

sn2.23:10.3.pli: Sādhu mayampi devaṃ nissāya dānāni dadeyyāma, puññāni kareyyāmā’ti.
sn2.23:10.3.eng: Your Majesty, please support us to give gifts and make merit.’

sn2.23:10.5.eng: ‘I’m a giver, a donor, who praises giving.

sn2.23:10.6.eng: When they say, “We would give gifts”, what am I to say?’

sn2.23:10.7.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, tatiyaṃ dvāraṃ balakāyassa adāsiṃ.
sn2.23:10.7.eng: And so I gave the third gate to my troops.

sn2.23:10.8.pli: Tattha balakāyassa dānaṃ dīyittha, mama dānaṃ paṭikkami.
sn2.23:10.8.eng: There they gave gifts, while my own giving dwindled.

sn2.23:11.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, brāhmaṇagahapatikā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
sn2.23:11.1.eng: Then my brahmins and householders approached me and said,

sn2.23:11.2.pli: ‘devassa kho dānaṃ dīyati; itthāgārassa dānaṃ dīyati; khattiyānaṃ anuyantānaṃ dānaṃ dīyati; balakāyassa dānaṃ dīyati; amhākaṃ dānaṃ na dīyati.
sn2.23:11.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty gives gifts, the ladies of your harem give gifts, your aristocrat vassals give gifts, your troops give gifts, but we don’t.

sn2.23:11.3.pli: Sādhu mayampi devaṃ nissāya dānāni dadeyyāma, puññāni kareyyāmā’ti.
sn2.23:11.3.eng: Your Majesty, please support us to give gifts and make merit.’

sn2.23:11.5.eng: ‘I’m a giver, a donor, who praises giving.

sn2.23:11.6.eng: When they say, “We would give gifts”, what am I to say?’

sn2.23:11.7.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, catutthaṃ dvāraṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ adāsiṃ.
sn2.23:11.7.eng: And so I gave the fourth gate to my brahmins and householders.

sn2.23:11.8.pli: Tattha brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ dānaṃ dīyittha, mama dānaṃ paṭikkami.
sn2.23:11.8.eng: There they gave gifts, while my own giving dwindled.

sn2.23:12.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, purisā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
sn2.23:12.1.eng: Then my men approached me and said,

sn2.23:12.2.pli: ‘na kho dāni devassa koci dānaṃ dīyatī’ti.
sn2.23:12.2.eng: ‘Now Your Majesty is not giving gifts anywhere!’

sn2.23:12.3.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, te purise etadavocaṃ:
sn2.23:12.3.eng: When they said this, I said to those men,

sn2.23:12.4.pli: ‘tena hi, bhaṇe, yo bāhiresu janapadesu āyo sañjāyati tato upaḍḍhaṃ antepure pavesetha, upaḍḍhaṃ tattheva dānaṃ detha samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavanibbakayācakānan’ti.
sn2.23:12.4.eng: ‘Well then, my men, deposit half the revenue generated in the outer districts in the royal compound. Give the other half as charity to ascetics and brahmins, to paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars in those districts.’

sn2.23:12.5.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, evaṃ dīgharattaṃ katānaṃ puññānaṃ evaṃ dīgharattaṃ katānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pariyantaṃ nādhigacchāmi—
sn2.23:12.5.eng: Sir, for a long time I made so much merit and did so many skillful deeds. I never reached any limit so as to say

sn2.23:12.6.pli: ettakaṃ puññanti vā ettako puññavipākoti vā ettakaṃ sagge ṭhātabbanti vāti.
sn2.23:12.6.eng: ‘there’s this much merit’ or ‘there’s this much result of merit’ or ‘for so long I’ll remain in heaven’.

sn2.23:12.8.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

sn2.23:13.2.eng: and a clear and confident heart,

sn2.23:13.4.eng: in this world and the next.

sn2.23:14.2.eng: overcoming that stain, and give a gift.

sn2.23:14.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn2.23:14.4.eng: support them in the next world.’”
